page.title: 13General Background
page.content: Elsenham village has existed since Saxon times. For most of that time most of the people worked the land. Earlier this century it was still possible to see flocks of sheep or herds of cattle being driven through the main streets to market in, for example, nearby Dunmow, or to the local railway station. Elsenham never had its own market. Over the years there have been many boundary changes. What is now Fullers End, an area of wealthy residents, was once the centre of Elsenham, and what now is the centre of Elsenham was once Henham. What really caused the expansion of Elsenham was the building of the M11 which allowed easy access to Cambridge and, in particular, London. Since the mid 70's when Elsenham was connected to mainline sewage over 500
